revision_history.draft:
# Witness

The ocean doesn't crash. It remembers.
I've watched it open its vast mouth like a jawbone
holding names—names worn smooth
until they are no longer legible, just shapes
the size of dinner plates, etched into the rind
of some ancient clamshell, kept in the deep.

There was a harbor once with a particular name.
Not on any chart. Not in any language
a minister would recognize. The stones
bore it for three hundred years—some kind of commitment,
the way someone presses their thumb
into soft clay to keep a promise visible.

Then the water found it, wore the syllables
down to their skeletons, to the hiss and grunt,
to what resembles a sentence no one
has finished saying. I read it wrong
a dozen times before I read it right,
and even then I can't be certain—I'm only
the first person in centuries to lean this close.

The tide goes in and out with equal purpose.
It doesn't crash. It executes
its planned withdrawal, leaving behind
what looks like effort, what looks like
an attempt at script: < = >, < = >,
each notch in the rock a mouth closing around air,

and I am the only one who has come here
to count it as language. The rest would call me
superstitious, or lost. But I have watched
the ocean swallow whole libraries
without once misplacing a single book.

It keeps what no one asked it to keep.
It stores the shape of a dock that was always wood,
the contour of a name even after the name
has passed into the kind of silence
that makes its own alphabet—dotted, dashed,
a Morse code nobody learned

because nobody sat here expecting
anything. I am not expecting.
I am only writing down what comes off
the rocks at low tide: < = >, < = >,
the way a finger traces letters
in the sand before it washes them clean.

And when the water returns it does not erase—
it superimposes, so each new wave
carries forward the work of all the waves
that came before it, and together they read
as something like an argument for patience:
how a reef takes nine hundred years
to build its claim against the light,

bricks of coral worn so thin
they could pass for teeth. I will not say
the ocean remembers what we didn't record.
I'll say this: it makes a better case

for it than any court in history ever did,
opening and closing its mouth like clockwork,
like something practicing for an entrance
it has never been asked to make. And still
it holds the shapes. Still reads them back.

To me, today.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The central conceit — the ocean as a witness that records names on rocks rather than waves crashing ashore — is genuinely compelling. The poem earns its argument through concrete physical detail: "the way someone presses their thumb / into soft clay to keep a promise visible" lands hard because it's rooted in tactile memory, not abstraction.

The passage beginning "I read it wrong / a dozen times before I read it right" works well — the repetition of misreading becomes an image for how meaning arrives through repeated attention rather than revelation. The shift from "wrong" to "right," then back into uncertainty ("even then I can't be certain"), is honest and earns its place.

The closing three lines — "Still reads them back. / To me, today." — close the poem with quiet authority because the accumulated physical detail has done the work before arriving there.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Abstraction bloat (lines 19–36).** The poem's second half dissolves into a catalog of vague oceanic abstractions: "effort, what looks like script," "a sentence no one / has finished saying." These lines are decorative rather than informative. **"A sentence no one / has finished saying"** is the worst offender — it tells us there's meaning without earning any through image or action. Direction: Every line in this section should contain a physical object, not a summary of what might be present.

**Cliché reappearing (line 21).** "The moon's gentle kiss" — the brief specifically named this as something to avoid, and it returns. This undermines trust between poet and reader. Direction: Cut or replace with an image that belongs only to *this* coastline.

**Redundancy / rhetorical inflation (lines 37–42).** "It doesn't crash. It remembers" — the opening line already stated this. The final three lines ("Still reads them back. / To me, today.") essentially repeat what was said in the closing image of the reef with coral teeth. **The poem's ending is doing less work than its middle section, which undermines both.** Direction: The ending needs to arrive *through* a new image or action, not summarize what has already been stated.

**"A Morse code nobody learned" (line 32).** This line gestures toward something interesting — the ocean as transmitter of secret language — but "nobody learned" is vague and unearned. Direction: What *did* it look like? A pattern in waves, a current's shape, something visible enough to be mistaken for code?

**Line breaks that don't break anything (lines 27–30).** "each notch in the rock

revision_history.draft:
The ocean doesn't crash. It remembers.
I've watched it open its vast mouth like a jawbone
holding names—names worn smooth
until they are no longer legible, just shapes
the size of dinner plates, etched into the rind
of some ancient clamshell, kept in the deep.

There was a harbor once with a particular name.
Not on any chart. Not in any language
a minister would recognize. The stones
bore it for three hundred years—some kind of commitment,
the way someone presses their thumb
into soft clay to keep a promise visible.

Then the water found it, wore the syllables
down to their skeletons, to the hiss and grunt,
to what resembles a sentence no one
has finished saying. I read it wrong
a dozen times before I read it right,
and even then I can't be certain—I'm only
the first person in centuries to lean this close.

The tide goes in and out with equal purpose.
It doesn't crash. It executes
its planned withdrawal, leaving behind
what looks like effort, what looks like
an attempt at script: < = >, < = >,
each notch in the rock a mouth closing around air,

and I have come here to count it as language—
the only one who has sat on this pier
expecting nothing. The water peels back
with such care it could be practicing
for some event it invented.

At low tide the rocks hold names
the ocean swallowed whole: a dock's wooden contour,
a wharf's particular decay, the phosphorus
of syllables worn to their mineral skeletons—< = >,< = >
each notch a brick in a reef of silence
taking nine hundred years to build its claim against the light,

bricks so thin they could pass for teeth. I will not say
the ocean remembers what we didn't record.
I'll say this: it makes a better case

for it than any court in history ever did,
opening and closing its mouth like clockwork,
like something practicing for an entrance
it has never been asked to make. And still
it holds the shapes. Still reads them back.

At my heel, a wave returns.
Not erasure—superimposition: each new crest
carrying forward the work of all the waves
that came before it, pressed together
into a single argument for patience,
how the reef advances brick by wornbrick,

how the water leaves its script on rock
the way a finger traces letters in the sand
before it washes them clean. Today I saw
something off the ledge at low tide—
< = >, < = > —the ocean's own punctuation,
each notch a mouth closing around air.
